content.description:
Starts with a V2/V3 boulder problem on the left or a 10+ delicate start on the right. I would be a good idea to avoid a fall before the end of either sequence - you may bounce off the anchor ledge before your first piece and get an ugly fall.


Then follows a thin finger tips appetizer section with good thin gear (finger size), then the crack disapears and you're at the 12- crux. Get some really thin gear in (those usually size as "0" or "00"), clean those shoes off any dirt, chalk up and get ready for thin, steep slab moves, before rejoining with some more finger crack awesomeness.



Directly above the belayer anchor on the ledge of the Boston Wall. 


Thin, thin gear. Both small nuts (3-5 stoppers) and cams (0, 0.1, 0.2) can come in handy. FInger stuff for the rest.

Excellent crack going up the upper slabs of the Boston wall Upper section of the "Mur de Boston". Can be more easily accessed by rappelling from the summit. To join the path, walk to the top of the center talus field and look for a narrow path going towards the lake. Exposed kiking traverse to reach two bolt.

You can also climb the slabs below and make a link up. Head a little left for the top of the slabs to easily locate the chains Double up to BD 0.75

From the belayer's anchor on the ledge, head up and right. Clip some kind of a bolt (a rivet!). Collect yourself, clean those shoes as best you can for optimal smearing, then finesse further right, struggle to place some gear to get the rivet (a rivet!) out of your mind and then go a little further until you manage to get into the vertical crack. Enjoy an awesome, sustained finger crack on good gear all the way up to the anchors.



On the Boston Wall ledge, thread right from Esprit d'Escaliers.

Mostly mid-small cams, good nuts placements as well.

Interesting dihedral. A very positive edge with good feet gradually narrows into a finger constriction, then into discontinuous finger pods (1 pad or so). Gets gradually harder as you go up, the crux being towards the top of the first part. Gets to a tree, then a 2nd shorter and easier (10-) section. Awesome technical corner, with good but not always obvious good gear. One just wish it was longer. Just above the Mur de Boston. See "Guide d'escalade de l'Estrie" p.26 (route #31). Decent gear exists but some care must be taken to ensure good placements towards the top as the finger-size crack at the front widens greatly at the back. Mostly finger sizes.

2-rings anchor at the top.
Enter a description of this area.
